header_summary:
VigSeth introduces the Twinstor Blockchain, a pioneering project aimed at developing a new Layer 1 protocol utilizing a Proof of Useful Work consensus mechanism for enhancing digital twin technologies across various industries such as automobile, aerospace, and consumer electronics. This protocol is designed to support over 1000 transactions per second, highlighting its scalability and performance. The project, which is ready for further development and collaboration, has secured a domain (twinstor.xyz) and shared a whitepaper for public review at [https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Xqfk99fbXz5ZSGiVSHeVhJi1bEUgCWuU/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Xqfk99fbXz5ZSGiVSHeVhJi1bEUgCWuU/view?usp=sharing), detailing its vision and technical framework ([Source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/new-paper-on-proof-of-usable-work/1867/2)).

On a different note, sanket1729 discusses an advancement in technology that potentially surpasses Jeremy Rubin's work for CTV, focusing on the use of Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) to enhance security and trust in computational processes. This discussion suggests a significant interest in the technology's deployment and operational aspects, indicating its readiness and potential for practical application in current systems, which could benefit from further exploration and discussion ([Source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/confidential-script-emulate-soft-forks-using-stateless-tees/1918/2)).

These discussions encapsulate the ongoing efforts and innovations in the blockchain and technology sectors, highlighting the development of new protocols and security measures aimed at improving scalability, performance, and trust in digital and computational processes.

active_posts.title: Correcting the error in getnetworkhashrateps
active_posts.summary:
- The current hash rate calculation overestimates due to a statistical error, needing adjustment.
- A proposed correction involves multiplying the estimate by (N-1)/N for accuracy.
- Switching to counting blocks over a fixed time period would better apply Poisson statistics.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin nodes and miners are adopting new policies like full replace-by-fee and spam filters.
- Compact block relay, since Bitcoin Core 0.13.0, enhances block propagation speed, reducing orphan rates.
- Alternative solutions like weak blocks and template sharing aim to improve network efficiency and privacy.

active_posts.title: Writing Simplicity Programs with SimplicityHL
active_posts.summary:
- Simplicity, designed for blockchain smart contracts, offers minimal design but is complex in use.
- SimplicityHL, a higher-level counterpart, aims to simplify development on Liquid and Elements platforms.
- It enables non-interactive fee bumping in Bitcoin transactions, enhancing smart contract functionality.

today_in_history_posts.title: Is there a tool like Ethereum EVM at present for Bitcoin script?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The author seeks a tool for writing bitcoin scripts in simpler syntax.
- They note bitcoin script's complexity hinders its technical promotion.
- Feedback on creating a user-friendly scripting language is requested.

today_in_history_posts.title: Do we really want users to solve an NP-hard problem when they wish to find a cheap way of paying each	other on the Lightning Network?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rene Pickhardt discussed the Lightning Network's non-linear function issues with ZmnSCPxj.
- ZmnSCPxj suggested a routing method for the Lightning Network and acknowledged its practical limitations.
- He also proposed adapting Pickhardt-Richter payments to incentivize `#zerobasefee`, possibly without a new LN implementation.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP Draft: Flag day activation based on nLockTime signaling
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The document proposes a novel soft fork activation process using `nLockTime` for Bitcoin.
- It provides a direct signaling method for community consensus, avoiding past controversies.
- Reference implementations and technical specifics are showcased via GitHub commits.
